When talking about what the scientific basis of a calorie, I think it’s also good to differentiate between a calorie and a Calorie. The calorie, as described in the video, is in fact the energy required to make 1 g (~0.035 ounces by weight, 0.034 fluid ounces by volume) of H2O increase by 1 degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit). For those of you who don’t know, this is not the number listed on the nutrition facts of foods. The nutrition facts list the Calories, also known as kilocalories. Essentially, one thousand calories equals one Calorie, and so one Calorie is the energy required for a kilogram (2.2 lbs) of H2O to increase by 1 degree Celsius. To put it into perspective, the average amount of energy people consume each day (taking 2350 based on the 2000-2700 estimate in the video) is enough energy to bring 23.5 kilograms of water from its freezing point to its boiling point. That is over 6 gallons of water. Furthermore, we, in general, expend that amount of energy each day through the activities we do.

So essentially, don’t let anyone tell you that you’re weak. You have the kind of power inside of you that can do incredible things, and you can probably do more than you think you can

This is a bit misleading, but it carries a good message.

When it comes to calories, they are NOT created equal, because our bodies burn and process protein, fats and carbs uniquely to each carbon group.

200 calories of oats will be digested and leave the stomach in as little as 50 minutes, carbs are our preferred energy source since for a long time we were herbivores, that's why they spike our blood sugar, and encourage the body to store excess glucosamine in fat cells.

fats and protein take much longer for us to break down, while more calorically dense, fats burn MUCH slower than carbs, keeping your blood sugars stable and uniform.

protein is even slower, taking 3-4 hours to leave the stomach, keeping you feeling full for longer, a calorie is just the measure of chemical energy released from actually burning food, it doesn't take into account our biology, and it misleads you into making calorie conscious food choices, avoiding fats in favor of carbs, when it's the carbs that contribute most to weight gain.

An avocado contains 320 calories! But 200 calories from sugar is 2.4 times as impactful on body weight, plus, we dont break down all the fats we eat for energy, much of an avocados fat content will instead be repurposed for your skins oil production, and brain development, so only about 60 "calories" will contribute to blood sugars from that 320.

(Or more if you have a fat rich diet and your body does rely on fats for energy, carbs are still good for you in the right quantity!)

End of the day, ignore calories and focus on iron content, nutrient profiles and keeping saturated fats out of your diet if possible, things like butter cheese ect are high sources of negative hdl cholesterol compounds, if a fat is solid at room temperature, it's not as biologically useful to you as a softer fat, seed oils like sunflower are much better for you than butter and hard cheeses.

What I like about counting calories is that bad behavior is punished right away. Like yesterday I decided I didn't want a healthy breakfast so I ate crepes. They were delicious, but not exactly filling. So today I'm eating better so I'm not hungry again. Because of this, I don't need cheat days, I just have days where I'm full and days when I'm less full, but I satisfied my craving, so it's worth it. The days where I eat less healthy end up encouraging me to eat healthier later, not discouraging me by making me feel like a failure.

Whereas with diets where I had to only eat certain foods, if crepes aren't on the menu, they'll NEVER be on the menu, which makes me sad and unsatisfied and more likely to eventually cheat.

you prolly here for a reason, idc if its gain weight, lose weight, jus be healthier, sum other bullshit, whatever. your diet is going to be THE MOST IMPORTANT THING no matter what. So do your research and figure out what works for you. But to the same end, keep things simple. If you wanna gain weight, eat a caloric surplus (200-500 should suffice, though personally i shoot for 800 because im trying to gain quicker), eat high amounts of protein and carbs (and a bit of fat cant hurt), and dont worry too too much about anything else. that doesnt mean just eat junk all the time, unless youre a dirty bulker, which means youre wierd. but if you wanna gain weight, you gotta have some cheat meals every now and then. If you wanna lose weight, eat a caloric deficit (again, 200-500), eat lots of less dense foods such as fruits and veggies so you can eat a higher volume and feel like youve taken in more than you actually have, and up your water intake just a tad. Don't wanna drink too much, because then you'll just start putting on waterweight more easily. anyways, thats all just my two cents, but make sure you do your own research, and dont take shortcuts. if it sounds too good to be true, at least in this kind of situation, it probably is.

NO, YOU ARE NOT!

You are what your body does to what you eat...

"Calories" is the most stupidiest concept in nutrition.

Your body doesn't care about "calories"!

That's because every specific nutrient has it specific metabolic pathway it is metabolized by. So 1 calorie of sugar is not the same as 1 calorie of fat or 1 calorie of protein. And many nutrients are actually signals which tell the metabolism to adapt. E.g. sugar signals to the body to gain weight and crave for more food. So it is much more about the the hormonal adaptations than about "calories".

"Counting calories" is just a complete bullshit which misses the real point.

I see you (we) all - or most of us - are s truggling in this comment section and honestly, seeing the comments, I feel like it can be quite toxic. I have an ED too so I really, really feel for all of you but you have to stay connected to reality a minimum. Anything under 1000 calories daily is really unhealthy, let alone if it’s for an extended period of time. Under 500 calories could drain your body and kill you in a few weeks, depending on how it reacts. It’s extremely dangerous, keep that in mind, even if we can’t get all the nasty voices out of your head. Try not to get carried away by other people living the same life as you and all acting like it’s normal... keep in mind that you’ll get out of the loop some day and you’ll finally remember how eating a lot isn’t evil, how it’s actually just pleasure and you don’t have to spend your life caring so much about so little. You owe it to your future and present self to do your best at not getting carried away. It’s gonna be okay, stay out here with us and stay conscious, I love you and you’re gonna get through it.

It’s not natural for humans to drink cow’s milk. Cow’s milk is a high fat fluid designed to turn a 30 kg baby calf into a 180 kg cow. Cow’s milk contains Animal protein- which has been proven by people like doctor T. Colin. Campbell to promote cancer growth. Animal Protein is far too acidic for the human body. In order to neutralise this acidity, the body leeches calcium and phosphorus from the bones. People have been mislead to believe that milk gives us strong bones, yet the countries with the highest dairy consumptions all have the highest rates of osteoporosis. Dairy products like cheese and butter are high in fat, saturated fat and cholesterol, and are very low in vital vitamins and minerals. Everybody is talking about eating less then you should, I don't know what I have, but everything I eat, I spend the next 15 minutes searching for its nutritional value and its calories. Not necessarily an eating disorder as I'm getting all of my nutrients and the perfect amount of calories. But I can tell you right now, from experience, eating less is not the way. I used to be so fat, now I have a six pack. Besides working out, diet is what's going to get you there. Now, "a healthy diet", what does that really mean? It doesn't mean eating rather unhealthy foods throughout the day (burgers, fries, cereal, etc.) and then having an 'extra healthy' salad for dinner. That won't really matter. What you need to do is make sure that al of the foods you are eating throughout the day are healthy, high in protein, and make sure you know your calories as well so you have a basic idea of how many calories you're having without research. For breakfast, include a boiled egg, FULL FAT milk, and a cottage cheese sandwich made with a low calorie omelette with protein bread as the bread. This is the perfect breakfast with high protein, healthy fats, optimal carbs and everything you need. Once you discover cottage cheese, it will seriously make everything easier while preparing a healthy breakfast. Now, for lunch and dinner, try to get fish, chicken or beef (no pork) along with spinach, arugula or any type of salad. You can try tuna, salmon, lamb, multiple different types of meat with different types of salads so you don't get bored. Obviously, you can eat something different every once in a while, but ALWAYS healthy. Don't believe in cheat days, you must LOVE the food you eat everyday. Try discovering different recipes with meat and salad until you find one you're in love with. Now, between breakfast and lunch or lunch and dinner, if you're going to snack, keep it light. Such as fruits (watermelon is always my #1) or vegetables (broccoli or edamame are great). I've gave you enough information to change your life, now it's up to you whether to act upon it or not.

This is wrong, he defined “calorie” correctly, but that’s not what “Calorie” means. American food companies thought people would be upset to see thousands of calories in food, so the opted to use kilocalories, or “Calories” with a capital C. The capital C means it’s kilocalories (only in the USA, other countries use kcal). So 1 Calorie on your dietary information label actually means enough energy to heat 1 kilogram of water 1 degree Celsius.

This video is great and informative! Great visual depiction of caloric density of foods. Basically High calorie dense vs low calorie dense foods. However, I think the point that the creator made regarding the health portion doesn't cover the full scope for the majority of the North American population.

The majority of people are grossly considered obese or overweight due to consuming highly caloric dense foods and over eating too many calories which results in carrying more body fat. Most people need to bring their body fat down into a healthier range as opposed to eating "healthier" foods. Which in media is being promoted as the solution. (Example eating avacadoos, nuts, salmon etc.)

Calories are a measure of energy expenditure so any calories not expended get stored as fat, in simple terms. Basically our bodies operate in calories IN vs calories Out. This is known in the bodybuilding world and fitness industry.

An example is if let's say someone were to substitute for the 2‰ milk(130cals) they consume for the diet cola (roughly 5cals, rounded to 0) that would actually be a benefit towards weight loss for the person as its less calories adding into their daily maintenance limits.

Point being that "healthy" does not equate to being fit or skinny if the right food options aren't made. I like the video but I think they could have covered more on this subject for the betterment of the industry.

Source: Greg Doucette (YouTuber) explains everything about nutrition but disclaimer he's not a doctor or nutritionist

Different foods are not digested at the same efficiency.

A Kcal is a measure of heat generated when food is tested in a calorimeter to see ho much water is heated. The numbers are potential Kcals not actual.

That's not how your intestines process food.

Different molecules are digested by different enzymes. Carbs are easily digested into sugars, proteins are digested more slowly, and fats are digested at a lower rate. So 500 Kcals of sugary food is absorbed more than 500 Kcals of fat as much of the fat passes undigested.

Eating fat doesn't make you fat, eating sugar makes you fat. You can ingest 2000 Kcals of fats a day and still lose weight.

The calorie is not a good measure of energy absorption.

Milk is horrible for your bones. It is very acidic to humans because cows milk wasn’t evolved for our smaller bodies. Plus human children take a very long time to fully grow (25 years) so we don’t need such a high concentration of nutrients. The excess will not be absorbed and will just be peed out. But calves are animals that turn into adults very quickly so they need the high concentration of acids and nutrients, plus they are much larger. When we drink cows milk the acidic nature of the non human milk is too much for our bodies. In order to neutralize ourselves we take the calcium from our own bones. Because our bones calcium is a base. Drinking high quantities of milk can lead to osteoporosis and general bone degradation in some cases. Milk is for infants and growing young children across ALL species. Milk was never meant to be consumed outside of that age and most certainly outside of our species. Different animals milk is designed for that specific animals needs and growing rates. Milk is unhealthy to adults. Milk is for babies and if that fact is offensive then I apologize.

I've lost 100 lbs and here's what I learned: calories are calories and sugars are sugars. There's also a huge difference between being healthy and losing weight. I know people a lot healthier than me that have an overweight BMI. This is strictly weight loss, not anything health related.

I base what I eat on the amount of sugar and carbs the food contains. I never eat apples because they're so full of sugar and high in carbs, on top of the taste of apples not being worth how much they "cost" in regards to the sugar and carb content. In fact, I rarely have fruits at all. The fruits I have are blackberries, green grapes (a maximum of 10 grapes), and blueberries. That's it. I eat a ton of vegetables like spinach, celery, brussel sprouts, etc and plenty of fish and chicken. Vegetables are lower in carbs than fruits, contain little to no sugar, and the amount of calories they're worth are so small that you can eat a lot and still barely scratch your calorie limit. Green is golden.

I also consume absolutely no dairy whatsoever. No dairy sugars, no proteins, and no milk fats. By eliminating dairy from your diet, you automatically eliminate most desserts, junk food, and calorie dense snacks. No more cheese danishes, no more vanilla or blueberry scones, no more cookies, no more this or that. The only desserts a person can have at that point are homemade which I do bake, but I also control ingredients and sugar content on those. So even my treats are less sugary.

If you want to also be healthy, keep track of nutrients and add supplements. I'm deficient in iron and B12, mostly because I only eat 500-600 calories a day. Eating healthy won't necessarily make you skinny, especially if you eat too many fruits and marinades and yogurt and whole milk etc, you have to restrict calories and keep track of the type of things you're eating.

In this video, you are talking about big calories, not small ones

This stuff is super important. As you ah e probably heard, losing weight is 70% diet and 30% exercise. 1 pound of fat or just under half a kilogram is equivalent to 3500 calories. If you cut your calorie intake everyday by 500 calories, you’ll lose a pound a week. The average American gains about 1 pound every week and a half. Just figure out your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR), which is the amount of calories you burn everyday on average. There are online calculators for it that are free. My BMR is about 2600 calories a day, I’m a 27 year old male. When I cut calories I try not to exceed the 2000 calorie mark. Remember it is okay to be hungry! We are used to eating as soon as we feel hunger but, we really don’t have to eat right away. Smaller portions and eating slowly, will help you eat less because it takes 15 - 20 minutes for our bodies to really know how much food we have consumed. This is why people stuff themselves super fast and then a half hour later sit there as if someone punched them in the stomach. They wonder why they are so full and lethargic. You WILL feel full even if you eat less. Good luck, I believe in you!

Milk has no "health benefits". It's not some crazy conspiracy or theory, although I know it sounds like it since every aspect of advertising has normalized the idea that milk is good for you...or even necessary for bone development. The truth is no mammal needs milk to survive after weening, if we did, there's no way we could have evolved before the point of pastoralism. The only organism that needs the milk of a cow for "health" is another baby cow.
Think about why that's so. Think about what milk does to a calf feeding from its mother. Milk from a cow is a cocktail of grown hormones designed to transform a calf into the size of a full grown cow in under a year. These hormones are not necessary humans in any way, shape, or form. Most especially, they are harmful when consumed by people who already suffer from being overweight or obese (which is 1/3 of Americans). More proof to this fact is seen in how the majority of us are incapable of digesting lactose, the sugars found in milk. Some are, only as a result of thousands of years of evolutionary change in response to the notion of keeping animals as pets and a food source. Basically, milk is not good for you. You don't need it to live. The only reason you hear about this non stop is that the dairy industry is worth billions of dollars, and they will push any lie to keep a profit.

This video fails to distinguish between a small calorie and a large calorie. A small calorie is the energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water through 1 °C (4.1868 joules), while a large calorie is the energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 kilogram of water through 1 °C, equal to one thousand small calories. The "calorie" used to measure the energy of foods in this video should be the "large calorie". 200 calories is the energy needed to raise the temperature of 200 kilograms of water through 1°C.

There is one major flaw in the script of the video, no distinction between calories and kilo-calories (kcal or food calories) was made in the video, yet you used both terms, I'm guessing without knowing. It takes 1 calorie to heat 1 gram of water by 1 degree Celsius, but the way we measure calories of food is in kcal which is 1,000 times more than one calorie. Meaning you can heat 1 kilogram of water by 1 degree Celsius using 1 kcal. Otherwise in the video it seemed that people would have to consume 1,000s of food calories to keep their bodies functioning as our bodies have many kilos of water, while 1 calorie (people thinking this is a food calorie) can only heat up 1 gram. Although I don't think you can change the video to somehow remove this mistake, hopefully you now know the difference between calories and kilo-calories so future videos aren't flawed. Also I hope you do more extensive research for your futures videos to prevent issues like this from happening again.

Great video! One thing to note though, while a calorie (cal) is the amount of energy is takes to raise 1 gram (Or mL) of water 1 degree Celsius, food calories are in kilocalories (Cal). A calorie (dietary calorie) is actually a Kilocalorie (Kcal) = the amount of energy it takes to raise 1,000 grams of water 1 degree Celsius. It's easier to remember that if one mL of water weights 1 gram then 1,000 ml of water (or 1 liter) weighs 1,000 grams. So, a dietary calorie is the amount of energy it takes to raise the temperature of 1 Liter of water by 1 degree Celsius.

Menstruation occurs because the uterine lining thickens with blood to prepare for a fertilized egg. If the egg is not fertilized, your body sheds both the unfertilized egg and the lining. It is painful because your uterus contracts and squeezes to loosen the lining and expel it from your body (cramps). Mood swings, acne, and binge eating that might accompany your menstruation are due to fluctuations in your hormones that are controlling these process, because hormones control ALL body functions.

Put simply, no. It's calorically neutral, but the artificial sweeteners used trick your brain into thinking you're hungry. When you drink Diet Coke your tongue tells your brain and body "prepare for sugar" because that's what it thinks it's getting, but the sugar never comes. There is actually a mistake in this video.  It is a common one when dealing with food packaging in the US.  A Calorie (with a capital C) is the amount of energy used to raise 1 kilogram of water by one degree.  This is what is printed on nutritional information in the United States.  A calorie (with a lowercase c) is energy to move one gram of water one degree.  Outside of the US a Calorie is commonly referred to as a kilocalorie.

This video needs to clarify the difference between a calorie and a Calorie (a.k.a. kilocalorie).  Here in America, our food is rated in Calories (capital 'C') which is actually 1000 heat calories, defined in the video as the amount of energy it takes to raise a milliliter (or gram, water's density is 1) of water one degree Celsius. 0.999.. = 1.

It's a mathematical proof, and a rather easy one at that:
Let x = 0.999.
 (Times by 10.)
So 10x = 9.999...
Now a simple step of taking x away from 10x.
10x - x = 9.999... - 0.999.... = 9.0
So 9x = 9.
And hence, x = 1.

Look at the first statement: x = 0.999...
And so, 0.999... = x = 1.
They're the same thing.

For a food calorie (Cal), the definition (at least in the US) is the energy needed to heat 1 kg of water 1° C. For just about any other use of the unit calorie (cal), the definition is the energy to heat 1 g of water 1° C. Thus, 1 Cal=1 kcal. Unfortunately, neither of these definitions is particularly useful, since the amount of energy varies depending on which pair of temperatures you move between and your atmospheric pressure. This is why the thermochemical definition 1 cal≡4.184 J is better.
